regretList.regret: Not striving to find my calling

Our aversion to loss is often greater than our affliction towards an equal gain. Along similar lines, I deeply regret trusting an unworthy man with my time and undue attention, and not giving up on him when I should have.
No regrets
I regret not having continued to stick to people who hurt me and insulted me during the worst days of my life. And not even realising how terrible they tried to make me feel
Not being open to all experiences. Not traveling and seeing the world.
Not making a move on a man I had strong feelings for.
Not keeping contact With Old friends
Never having raised a child or children.
Not taking more chances, playing it too safe!
Playing it safe, not taking chances for fear of failure.

When I was in high school I was a terrible student. I wasn't stupid, just lazy. I didn't realize I was smart so I didn't really try. This created an inner need to feel like I was always catching up. I didn't step in the gas until I was in college but always felt like the time wasted would never be made up. I still feel like I'm catching up more than 30 years later.
I wish I had completed a different graduate school program.
I regret not suing the immigration office with a petition to stop the over population that has ruined the ability to restore farming and stop production based on greed.
Not understanding better, at 18/19, how to take care of my dying mother, and not realizing I needed to ask many questions to which only she would have the answers.

Leaving a company for a little more money, but later regretting it as the new firm's boss is crazy and the culture sucks

I also regretted being late in realizing that family, not work, is irreplaceable.

- CarlA
I hope I still have custody of my two daughters.
Unprepared to be loved, I recoiled into the arms of familiar loneliness.
Choosing to act in a way not true to myself as a young adult. Behaved in a way I thought my parents would want me to, not following my heart.
Not following my gut instinct about my first wife. She was a mistake, and my head talked over my gut--much to my regret.

I grew up poor and swore I would never live that way as an adult. My first love was a musician and struggling financially when we were in our teens and 20s. I left that relationship because I thought he could never provide financial security for me, and I wish I would’ve had the courage and the strength to realize that I could provide for us financially and he could pursue his music while caring for our children. Failing to think outside the box and be brave led  me to lose the person who meant the most to me.

Not maximizing our investment into our house. My husband and I purchased our home using very conservative figures for our future earnings. We bought a house that was relatively small with fewer bedrooms that we needed and assumed we would expand if we needed to. Expanding turned out to be impractical and expensive, as did moving later given the rise in housing costs, and now we’re a family of five crammed into a small house that doesn’t fit our needs.
I wish I had more fun
Had to less focus on my career - I performed all the years but didn't know to sell myself enough.
I regret not learning and practicing the skills to be a better friend

1) Working too much and not enough time with family and other areas of life improvement. 2) Came from a lower/middleclass family and worked hard to get into a top University. It was hard being surrounded by so many people of wealth (via cars, clothes, dorm accessorizing etc) and got swept away into parties and trying to be popular. My studies were pushed aside which is how I got in in the first place. Thus I regret not reflecting on my choices, not putting education first, and trying to be a people pleaser and subsequently a pushover and manipulated. Now I cannot support my family in the way I want to, yet am working hard to make up for it. However, once you fail in academia, the gates seem to be permanently shut. Education is important and should not be wasted. It should also be ubiquitously accessible.

This regret isn't as strong as it was before COVID-19 (I'm beginning to recognize the power of a "name brand" school), but 3 years post grad, I regret spending $240k on a "good" university. My friends who went to state schools are just as successful, if not more successful, than me, so I kick myself for collecting so much debt through a decision I made at 18 when had no idea what I wanted to do with my life. There are so many things I want to do and see - even alternate careers, but a massive cloud of debt (not only my own debt, but also my parents' contribution/investment) looms over my head at every decision. I don't think my dad's advice of "it will pay off!" is true so far, but maybe I'll change my mind one day.

Given an opportunity to change directions in my career, moving toward a field closer to my passions, skills and expertise, and to relocate back to the southwest which I love so much, I made a decision to stay in order to maintain a relationship that ultimately resulted in a marriage and three children, infidelity, emotional abuse and divorce. I made what I thought was the right choice at the time based on the limited information I had and having learned more, realize I should have gone the other way.
Wish I chose a different career path. Wish I worked harder while training for athletics in high school.
Not pursuing the degree I actually wanted, namely history, in favour of what seemed better (and easier) at the time. It felt vaguely wrong but I ignored it.
Regret of to much shyness to overcome fear of crisism from others, as a result i postpone things. Don’t ask easy for help from others.
Pursuing long distance relationships through and post college that took away from the experiences I could have been having at that age

I regret that I’ve not forged lasting significant relationships with others, opting instead for superficial, if amicable, relationships. I also regret that, in relationships that are significant, lasting & vulnerable - like my marriage - I’ve violated and sabotaged the relationships, making trust tenuous and the relationships less open & vulnerable.
Not managing my finances well when I was younger
I regret caring what other people think.

When I hear about the mamba mentality of Kobe Bryant I regret not applying a formula or level of commitment he applied. I have Been moderately successful but I will know the potential I could have realized.
Made a career change earlier, and taken bigger risks when younger.
Smoking!!!
I regret letting my weight increase consistently over the last 23 years. At 33 it defines me and I am at the point where I am not sure how to go back.
I regret (at times) that I didn’t take the safe option with employment decisions. This occurs when I’m going through a rough work/life patch.
Staying in an unhealthy relationship for much longer than I should have done. Not only was this bad for my well-being, it may have also resulted in me losing the opportunity to have a child.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret:
I regret that I make all my decisions considering what it will make other people think of me rather than how it will make me feel.
And although I have a wonderful life, I wonder regularly where I would be (for the better or worse) if my decisions were just mine.

I regret not travelling more in my 20s 
I regret having sex with men in my 20s who didn't deserve or appreciate me but that wasn't secure enough in myself to know that I was worth more.
More recently I regret that the person I take my insecurities and my fears of those past regrets out on, is the person who loves me the most.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Stupid mistakes in my teens which made me feel like a bad person for years and still stirs regret and shame now

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Didn’t take CBT counselling when I needed it

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Not pushing myself hard enough

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: That I couldn't make my marriage work.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: I lost my job where I found an incredible team.
To not have had the courage to be a single mom from the start

While married I allowed myself to spend time around someone else to whom I was attracted.  No physical unfaithfulness occurred, but I cannot say that there was no emotional unfaithfulness.  I thought it was safe, but their was interference - like loud static over a radio program - to my affections for my spouse. It took 2 years to completely overcome.
I was not nearly kind enough during my youth.
I wish I had been a better big sister to my little brother.
Not learning to play a music instrument when was young
I regret not spending more time with my grandparents and older relatives, so I could have a better appreciation for my current situation, as compared to them.
That I didn't make more chances in finding a way to make a living that was engaging and not just practical and responsible. Now I'm 60 and it feels too late.
Being so naive in my early 20s and thinking that other people shared my belief in having their best interests at heart, led to a cheating spouse before and during my short marriage.
I regret not pursuing teaching internationally when I graduated from college.
To much time spent watching TV and focusing on sports; and not enough on clubs / activities in my formative years of high school and university... thinking ski club, chess club, debate class, etc.
After working for UPS, I had the idea for a Mailboxes Etc. type company. My regret was believing UPS when they said they would never leave a package with me.
I regret that President Trump can't have one nice thing come out of his mouth. He is rubbing off on everyone else .It encouraged other people to spout their hate also.
Failing to learn a foreign language.
Lived a more carefree simpler life with less acquisition of material goods.
I regret not exploring additional careers that could have been more fulfilling.
I regret that I spent years smoking pot when I was a young adult.
That I have tried to be somebody I was not.
Teaching is my passion and, though I loved the job (US Government) I ended up in for the past 35 years, I regret that I did not pursue educational degree in college and then teaching as a career.
Moving back to the United States after living in Germany for a few years.
I regret not leaving toxic relationships with men earlier and not having a tribe/family who could raise alarm bells when even I did not or refused to see them.
How I treated friends who annoyed me in school
I didn’t become a focyor
My attitude and behaving towards some people in my private life in the past.
not spending enough time with
Not making enough art

I regret that I wasn’t more confident in myself to take risk and be decisive  when I was in my 30s and even now. Although I’m confident that life is unfolding as it should and I am responsible for my own life I do regret not standing up for myself and blaming external factors. Had I done that years ago maybe more people who have been would’ve been employed by this really cool program.
Waiting around for someone who obviously didn't want me.
